item.title: 5 Democratic States Sue Trump Administration Over $10 Billion Funding Freeze
item.description: The administration cited without evidence “potential” widespread fraud in its move to cut off funds for child care subsidies and other support for low-income families.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Department of Health and Human Services had announced this week it was freezing funds for California, Colorado, Illinois, Minnesota and New York.

item.title: Amid Protests, ICE Told Agents to Take ‘Decisive Action’ if Threatened
item.description: The guidance comes as immigration officers have been met with increasingly hostile protesters in cities.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:description: Federal officers clashed with protesters, some of whom threw snowballs, in Minneapolis on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Feels ‘Strongly’ That Russia Would Not Invade Ukraine Again
item.description: The president told The Times that he felt “strongly” that Russia would not invade Ukraine again.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Ukraine’s 148th Artillery Brigade firing toward Russian targets in eastern Ukraine in October.

item.title: U.S. Border Patrol Agents Shoot 2 in Portland During Traffic Stop
item.description: The shooting came as Minneapolis grappled with a federal agent’s killing of a woman a day earlier, prompting calls from local leaders for an end to the Trump administration’s immigration crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Anna Griffin, Hamed Aleaziz and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers blocked off an area near where victims of a shooting involving federal agents were found in Portland, Ore., on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Sees AI’s Economic Promise, While Dismissing Potential Threats
item.description: The president said that artificial intelligence would create such an abundance of jobs that robots would be required to fill the gaps.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Ivan Pierre Aguirre for The New York Times
item.media:description: The construction site for Project Jupiter, a proposed A.I. data center planned by OpenAI and Oracle, in Santa Teresa, N.M.

item.title: Senate Agrees to Display a Jan. 6 Plaque Honoring Officers
item.description: Federal law mandated that the memorial tablet be installed by March 2023, but Congress blew past that deadline.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: A plaque honoring law enforcement officers who responded to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol is set to hang in the Senate wing after a bipartisan resolution was unanimously adopted.

item.title: Trump Backs RFK Jr.’s Moves on New Childhood Vaccine Schedule
item.description: In an interview with The New York Times, the president said that Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. had not gone too far in his recommendations.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:description: The number of child vaccinations recommended by the government has declined.

item.title: Bondi Warns Minnesota Protesters to Stay Away From Federal Agents
item.description: Trump administration officials also spent the day attacking the woman killed by an ICE agent.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague, Devlin Barrett and Ashley Ahn
item.media:description: Vice President Vance during a news briefing at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: The Next Phase of Trump’s Renovations: A New ‘Upper West Wing’
item.description: Besides changes to the White House, President Trump also said he planned to tear up the brick walkways in Lafayette Park and replace them with granite.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers, Luke Broadwater, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Tyler Pager
item.media:description: In President Trump’s vision, a second level with office space would be built on top of the colonnade that connects the West Wing to the White House residence.

item.title: House Passes Doomed Bill to Restore ACA Subsidies
item.description: The passage of the bill was a triumph for Democrats, who drew substantial Republican backing. But it has no path forward, and an election-year compromise is a long shot.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold and Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Morgan Lieberman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Millions of Americans have relied on subsidies, which were expanded during the coronavirus pandemic, to help them afford coverage on federal health care exchanges.

item.title: Trump Urges Voters to Oust Republicans, Including Susan Collins
item.description: After five G.O.P. senators joined Democrats on a war powers vote, the president lashed out, including at his party’s most politically endangered senator.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Susan M. Collins, Republican of Maine, was one of five Republicans who voted with Democrats to start a debate over restricting the president’s ability to use military force in Venezuela. Of the five, Ms. Collins is the only one up for re-election this year.

item.title: These 5 Republicans Broke With Trump on Venezuela War Powers
item.description: The Republican defectors paved the way for a debate that could expose bipartisan concern about President Trump’s actions in Venezuela. Mr. Trump called for them to lose their seats.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Senator Susan Collins is the only one of the five Republican defectors who is facing re-election this year.

item.title: The Many Faces of Trump: What We Saw When We Interviewed the President
item.description: He let reporters in on a call with Colombia’s president. He complained about Zohran Mamdani. He called JD Vance and Marco Rubio “kids.” Inside an unpredictable evening with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Doug Mills
item.media:description: President Trump spent nearly two hours being interviewed by New York Times reporters on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Says He ‘Probably Should’ Take Obesity Drugs, but Has Not
item.description: President Trump has talked in the past about people he knows who have taken “the fat drug.”
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.media:description: President Trump said he has not taken GLP-1 drugs.

item.title: Russian Propaganda Ramps Up After U.S. Raid in Venezuela
item.description: A network of websites known as “Portal Kombat” is spreading messages about U.S. military hardware, according to tracking firms.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Red Square in Moscow. Russia and Venezuela have had a close diplomatic relationship, and Moscow is keen to retain those ties.

item.title: Fact-Checking Trump’s Justifications for the Venezuela Operation
item.description: The president has repeatedly tied Venezuela to drug overdose deaths, claimed the Maduro regime sent an influx of criminal migrants and accused the country of stealing American oil.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at a news conference on Saturday at Mar-a-Lago.

item.title: Congress Tries, but Fails, to Take a Stand for Its Own Powers
item.description: House votes to override a pair of Trump vetoes were an unusual bid by some in the G.O.P. to assert their own branch’s prerogatives. But they fell short.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:description: The move was described by one of President Trump’s allies as designed to “slap the president in the face.”

item.title: G.M. Books a $7.1 Billion Loss as It Scales Back E.V. Ambitions
item.description: General Motors said it was writing down the value of battery and electric vehicle factories after changes in federal policy undercut demand.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Battery assembly at a General Motors facility in Spring Hill, Tenn. Electric cars have become more difficult to sell since the elimination of federal tax credits last year.

item.title: Trump ‘Always’ Respects Election Results, but in the U.S., He Says They’re ‘Rigged’
item.description: Over the years, the president has consistently sought to undermine faith in the voting process.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: President Trump speaking to reporters from The New York Times in the Oval Office on Wednesday.

item.title: House Passes Spending Package Before Another Shutdown Deadline
item.description: The legislation would fund parts of the government ahead of a Jan. 30 deadline in a bipartisan breakthrough after the nation’s longest shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: The package still must pass the Senate before it can be sent to Mr. Trump, but it appeared to be on track for enactment.

item.title: Trump Says He Has No Issue With His Family’s Foreign Business Deals
item.description: The president, in an interview with The New York Times, said he showed restraint during his first term but got no credit for it, so he saw no reason to hold back now.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere
item.media:credit: Ahmed Gaber for The New York Times
item.media:description: The president’s comments come after a year in which his family has engaged in a profit-making campaign like none in modern American history.

item.title: Sean Combs Requested a Pardon in a Letter, but Trump Is Unimpressed
item.description: President Trump told The New York Times in an interview that he was not considering pardoning the music mogul.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel
item.media:description: Sean Combs, who is serving a 50 month sentence for prostitution-related charges, requested a pardon from President Trump in a letter, the president said on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Criticizes ICE for an Anti-Business Immigration Raid
item.description: But the president did not personally criticize Stephen Miller, the architect of his administration’s restrictive immigration policy, who has pushed to significantly limit visas for skilled workers.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: Stephen Miller, White House deputy chief of staff, in the Oval Office in October.

item.title: Trump Addresses Venezuela, Greenland and Presidential Power in New York Times Interview
item.description: On topic after topic, President Trump made clear that he would be the arbiter of any limits to his authorities, not international law or treaties.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Tyler Pager, Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

item.title: Denaturalization Is Part of Trump’s Crackdown on Immigrants
item.description: The administration is looking at Somali-born American citizens as well as other groups, but the president did not specify which.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Ben Brewer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Minneapolis is home to one of the largest Somali-American communities in the United States.

item.title: Lynda Blackmon Lowery, One of the Youngest Selma Marchers, Dies at 75
item.description: Her activism began as a teenager in 1963, when she heard the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. speak. It set her on a path to nonviolent protest.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Lynda Blackmon Lowery in 2015, at the New York Historical, a museum in Manhattan. She said she was arrested nine times before she turned 15 for participating in civil rights protests.

item.title: Trump Says He Has Made Up His Mind on His Fed Chair Pick
item.description: The president stopped short of announcing his selection, but when asked about Kevin A. Hassett, his top economic adviser, he said he was “certainly one of the people that I like.”
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:description: Kevin A. Hassett at the White House.

item.title: After ICE Shooting, Trump Administration Deploys More Agents to Minnesota
item.description: More than 100 agents will be redirected from other cities after the fatal shooting of a woman in Minneapolis by an ICE officer.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz and Madeleine Ngo
item.media:description: The increased presence of Border Patrol agents is expected to last through the weekend, with a planned return to their cities on Sunday.

item.title: Prosecutors Said to Pursue New Investigation of Letitia James
item.description: A longtime hairdresser for the New York attorney general has come under scrutiny as the Justice Department’s efforts to charge Ms. James on other fronts falter.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Mimi d’Autremont for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has explicitly pushed for the prosecution of Letitia James, the New York attorney general and one of his foremost nemeses.

item.title: Senate Advances Measure to Curb Trump’s Use of Force in Venezuela
item.description: A handful of Republicans joined Democrats to allow the measure to move forward, reflecting concerns in both parties about the administration’s strategy.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: “Make no mistake: Bombing another nation’s capital and removing their president is an act of war, plain and simple,” Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, said before the vote.

item.title: Thomas Massie Thinks Trump and Republicans Are ‘Gaslighting’ on Venezuela
item.description: Representative Thomas Massie, a rare Republican critic of President Trump’s military intervention, explained his concerns in an interview with The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Thomas Massie, Republican of Kentucky, in November. In an interview on Wednesday, he slammed “a flimsy constitutional argument” for the United States’ seizure and prosecution of Venezuela’s leader.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Congress Challenges Trump on Vetoes, Health, War and Spending
item.description: A packed voting schedule on Capitol Hill is showcasing rare glimmers of Republican resistance to President Trump and his agenda.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: House Republicans were expected to override two presidential vetoes on Thursday.

item.title: Josh Shapiro Starts a New Chapter, Attacking the ‘Toxicity in D.C.’
item.description: Kicking off his re-election bid, the Pennsylvania governor warned against federal overreach and promised, “I will not let anyone mess with a Pennsylvanian.”
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen for The New York Times
item.media:description: At a lively rally at a carpenters’ technical center in Pittsburgh, Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania reintroduced himself as a pragmatic politician focused on economic growth and affordability, public safety and education.

item.title: Tips for Caribbean Vacations and Travel Insurance After Venezuela Operation
item.description: The recent military operation in Venezuela disrupted vacations to popular destinations. Here are tips for buying travel insurance and protecting your trip.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Passengers were stranded at Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport near San Juan, P.R., last weekend after the F.A.A. closed some airspace to U.S. civilian aircraft.

item.title: Minimum Wage Rises in Some States as Workers Struggle With Basic Costs
item.description: This year, for the first time, more Americans will earn a minimum wage of $15 per hour or higher than will earn the federal minimum of $7.25 per hour.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch
item.media:description: A sign at a Raise the Wage Act rally on the National Mall in March 2021.

item.title: The Smithsonian Faces New Pressure to Submit to Trump’s Will
item.description: The institution, long regarded as independent, is facing a White House deadline to hand over records about its content and will see turnover that could reshape its governing board.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley and Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Salwan Georges/The Washington Post via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Smithsonian, which has resisted White House efforts to oversee its operations, is facing a deadline next week to turn over records about its programming and other matters to the Trump administration.

item.title: We Pressed Trump on His Conclusion About the ICE Shooting in Minneapolis. Here’s What He Said.
item.description: The exchange was a glimpse into the president’s reflexive defense of his federal crackdown on immigration.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Natalie Harp, a presidential aide, showing a video of the fatal shooting in Minneapolis to President Trump and reporters from The New York Times on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Sits Down With Times Reporters for Two-Hour Interview
item.description: In a wide-ranging conversation with four Times reporters, President Trump talked about the Minneapolis ICE shooting, immigration, Venezuela and even his plans for further White House renovations.
item.media:description: New York Times journalists interviewing President Trump in the Oval Office on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Says U.S. Oversight of Venezuela Could Last for Years
item.description: In a wide-ranging interview with The New York Times on Wednesday, President Trump said “only time will tell” when it comes to how long the United States aims to control the country.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Tyler Pager, Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: President Trump in the Oval Office with Vice President JD Vance and Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Wednesday.
